comment: The textbook was still being written and we were given the rough drafts to study the quizzes, and the labs were not given to us until midterms. He took around 48 hours to respond to emails as well. All the information that you need for the exams & quizzes is in the textbook, the lectures didn't help. Cyberbit labs sucked very much. Good luck.
rating_tags: Lots of homework--Beware of pop quizzes

comment: Professor Harris is very hands off. He would let us know when the content for each chapter was available and give reminders the day of exams. Other than that just read the chapter for that week and do the quizzes. Also started doing labs on Cyberbit halfway into the semester, but it was very straightforward.

Professor Harris is a part time professor with a full time job the semester turned out surprisingly well. Starting with the pros: he puts grades in that same week instead of waiting til the end of the semester, and he has lectures that actually cover what is on the quizzes. Cons class was boring and network security is an interesting subject to me
rating_tags: Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria

comment:
I contacted the professor and explained to him I had a dear friend commit suicide early in the semester. My friends passing took a huge toll on my mental health and some days I could not finish a few labs and quizzes.
I ended the class with a 69.27, and the professor refused to round it.

Overall easy class would take him again.

Overall, easy course, and not a bad professor (compared to other reviews). Weekly labs and quizzes which are very easy and midterm/final (open notes). He is a part-time professor so it makes sense for him not to be very hands-on but the work is very easy and not complicated at all. Would take him again if I had the chance.

Avoid this miserable life professor at all costs. He gives 0 care for you as a student. He does the bare minimum for his job and clearly does not care at all for his students or their success in the course or as a student as a whole.

Professor Harris takes eons to reply to questions and resolve problems. When he does finally reply to student questions he is downright unhelpful and borderline rude. His tone in correspondence spoke down to us as if he was babysitting unruly children.  It was clear to most students in the class that Professor Harris has other priorities.

Do not take this professor. His course content is out of date by a lot of years, he is slow at responding, and when he does respond to emails, he is not lenient at all. Emails sent for the most minor mistakes in his homework are brushed off and are left to fend for yourself. He is brutal. Do not expect any help from him in the class. It's awful.

He has a full time job outside of teaching and makes it clear that teaching is not a priority. Takes weeks to reply to email. Requires $80 software to do labs that are out of order, doesn't explain assignments well, and is not understanding. The textbook is not necessary. The three timed tests totaling 60% are a lot of questions for little time.

I would definitely recommend: Easy professor and easy assignments. Weekly labs and quizzes; 3 exams that are 2-part and open-book (no midterm or final); one discussion; one paper. Not much reading! Prof. Harris allows resubmissions and late submissions if you've got a good reason (don't slack off). Overall, it's an easy and fun A!
rating_tags: Accessible outside class--Graded by few things--Caring

comment: Professor Harris provides recorded lectures and PowerPoints regularly. He is communicative and will respond to emails within a day or so. There are weekly quizzes and easy labs, three open-book exams, and 5 brief summary write-ups. The textbook is required but interesting. Study, and it's an easy A!
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Get ready to read--Clear grading criteria

comment: There are performance labs for each chapter. 3 tests, all are open book. Not hard to get an A as long as you somewhat prepare for them. Solid professor. Responds to questions within a reasonable time. You will need the textbook. The tests and quizzes are w/o lockdown and unlimited but averaged out of all attempts.

Concept of the class is important but with limited directions its hard to get far without asking classmates. He is not informative when directly asked questions about the projects. Im glad I passed. Im not sure if I could take this class again even if you paid me
rating_tags: Get ready to read--So many papers--Tough grader

comment: Best prof so far in the Cybersecurity/Computer Science etc.. department. Clear grading criteria, responds quickly to email and discussion posts. Grades rather quickly w/ good feedback on positives and negatives. Labs due every week but that's to be expected w/ this course, labs not difficult at all.
rating_tags: Gives good feedback--Clear grading criteria--EXTRA CREDIT

comment: There was a quiz and performance lab for each chapter. Read and follow instructions carefully. If you put in some effort, you'll do fine. He is extremely knowledgable about security and also responds with great advice! I took the course online, but wish I got to meet him in person.

Professor Harris is amazing for ISA 3210 and 3200! He makes everything very clear and is very generous with due dates. The class is pretty easy with labs, quizzes, professional engagements, and tests. If you read the book or understand the material, its an easy A!
rating_tags: Clear grading criteria--GRADED BY FEW THINGS--Caring

comment: Online class with lots of quizzes, homeworks, & some discussion postings in this class. The quizzes most answers found online or in lecture slides, and the latter 2 can be B.S.'d easily. Tests are extremely hard due to time allowed for completion vs. # of questions to answer, but there are ways around this difficulty ;).  SUPER long term paper.

There is a quiz for every chapter and you have a week to do it. There are 7 assignments that deal with business/disaster recovery. The quizzes are super easy, but the two exams are difficult. Not so much hard questions, just to many in the time period. There is a paper and isn't clear for what he wants on it. He works full time in the real world.
